scenes.dialogue_vo: Want an expert system in 60 seconds? Meet CLIPS — rule-based brain power for your programs. Fast, nerdy, and actually useful. Let’s go! (Blink-and-you’ll-miss-it pace.)
Quick pitch: CLIPS is multi-paradigm — rule-based, object-oriented, procedural. It holds knowledge as facts, reasons with rules, and runs an inference engine that decides what to do next.
First — facts. Facts are chunks of data: a relation name and slots. Define their shape with deftemplate so your facts aren’t a messy pile of tokens.
Here’s a deftemplate and an asserted fact. Watch the structure + content combo — it’s how CLIPS keeps knowledge readable and reloadable.
Want to load a whole bunch of initial facts? Use deffacts. It’s like a snapshot of your world that you can assert as a group.
Rules: left-hand side matches facts, right-hand side does stuff. The inference engine matches patterns, activates rules on an agenda, and fires them.
Debugging: watch facts and rules, inspect the agenda, and use refraction to avoid repeated firings. No more guesswork — just actionable traces.
Pattern power: variables, single-field wildcards, and multifield variables let you match flexible shapes of data — from rigid literal matches to galaxy-level pattern tricks.
Manipulate facts with assert, retract, and modify. Want to remove or update knowledge? Do it cleanly — preserving fact-ids can matter for refraction and rule semantics.
Extra tools: list and delete constructs, save/load facts, step execution (run 1) for breakpoints, and watch for fast debugging. Combine these to tame complex rule sets.
Recap: facts = data, deftemplates/deffacts = structured knowledge, rules = behavior, agenda + inference engine = control. Use variables and wildcards to make rules expressive.
Want a crash-course project? Try building a tiny expert system: define templates, create deffacts, write 4–5 rules, debug with watch, and iterate. Follow for more CLIPS deep dives!

asset.description: Camera starts with an extreme close-up of a cluttered programmer’s desk at 3 a.m., littered with energy drink cans, a rubber duck, and a half-eaten slice of pizza balanced precariously on a mechanical keyboard. A frazzled person in pajama pants and a blazer jacket suddenly jerks into frame from below, slamming their hands on the desk as three computer monitors flash the word “HELP” in giant red terminal text. The camera snap-zooms out to reveal a fourth monitor above them, mounted crookedly, showing an absurd stock photo of a glowing cartoon brain wearing sunglasses and spinning slowly like a 3D logo. The person dramatically rips off a pair of over-ear headphones, stares deadpan into the camera, then points both index fingers at the floating brain monitor just as the word “CLIPS” appears in chunky neon letters. The lighting flickers between cold blue and warm orange like a broken club strobe, while a desk fan blows sticky notes labeled “TODO” across the scene in slow motion. The person mimes checking a nonexistent watch, looks shocked at the invisible time, and then speed-scrolls nonsense code on one of the screens using exaggerated, frantic hand motions, as if casting a spell on the monitors while the brain spins faster, leaving a faint motion blur trail.

bgm: High-energy electronic beat, fast tempo, glitchy but playful, immediately in from 0s.

asset.description: The shot opens on a wide overhead view of a human lying flat on the floor in the shape of a starfish, surrounded by three hula hoops labeled with badly hand-drawn marker text: “rules,” “objects,” and “procedures.” The person is wearing a business shirt tucked into sweatpants and mismatched socks, and their hair is sticking straight up from static. As the camera slowly spirals downward, the person scoots clumsily into the “rules” hoop, holds up a notebook with the word “FACTS” scribbled across it, and nods solemnly to no one. They then awkwardly roll sideways into the “objects” hoop, instantly don a pair of fake glasses from their pocket, and begin arranging random household items—like a banana, a stapler, and a rubber chicken—into careful rows as if they are a serious taxonomy. The camera cuts to a low side angle right as they worm crawl on elbows into the “procedures” hoop, where they frantically press an unplugged game controller’s buttons while glancing up at a nearby laptop that only shows a big spinning loading icon. Behind them, a cheap party fog machine spurts a tiny cloud of smoke right on cue as a crudely drawn cardboard sign reading “INFERENCE ENGINE” dangles from the ceiling and slowly swings over their head like a malfunctioning halo.

bgm: Quirky, nerdy lo-fi beat with light synth arpeggios, steady but not aggressive.

asset_plan.scene_name: Scene 3 – Messy Tokens vs Structured Facts

asset.description: Camera opens on a chaotic kitchen table covered in tiny paper scraps, each scrap bearing a single random word like “blue,” “42,” “chicken,” and “true,” all scattered in a hopeless pile. A confused person in an oversized lab coat and safety goggles sits at the table, trying to assemble a sentence by rapidly picking up scraps and reading them aloud in the wrong order, then grimacing and tossing them back in frustration. The camera tilts slowly downward as their hands dig through the word pile with increasing desperation until they suddenly freeze, glance conspiratorially at the camera, and pull out a pristine clipboard labeled “deftemplate.” In one exaggerated motion, they sweep all the loose scraps into a shoebox labeled “MESSY TOKENS” and shove it to the very edge of the table, nearly knocking it off. The camera then tracks in as they methodically place a few chosen paper scraps into a tidy plastic organizer with compartments labeled “relation,” “slot 1,” “slot 2,” and “slot 3,” tapping each slot with a proud flourish. They sit up ramrod straight, adjust a completely unnecessary stethoscope around their neck as if diagnosing the data, and give a comically slow thumbs-up directly into the lens while the chaotic shoebox wobbles unsteadily in the background.

bgm: Light playful pizzicato strings with a subtle clockwork feel, mid-tempo.

asset.description: Shot begins with a tight close-up of a blank whiteboard, filmed slightly off-kilter so the corners look skewed. A hand suddenly slaps a magnetic card labeled “deftemplate” onto the board with ridiculous force, making the camera quiver. The camera slowly dollies sideways as the same hand draws four perfectly straight lines beneath it using a neon ruler, creating cartoonishly labeled boxes like “relation,” “slot: name,” and “slot: value.” The hand then theatrically flicks a second magnetic card labeled “fact” from off-screen; it spins end-over-end in midair in slow motion before smacking onto the whiteboard right under the template, aligning as if it’s being magnetically snapped into place. The shot cuts to a side angle as the person, now visible wearing an office shirt paired with bright dinosaur-print pajama shorts, steps into frame and dramatically plugs a completely unconnected USB cable into the bottom of the whiteboard as though powering it up. Instantly, hand-drawn arrows appear one by one connecting the template boxes to the fact card, while the person traces each arrow with their finger and nods along like a conspiracy theorist explaining a wall-of-string diagram to an invisible audience.

bgm: Calm but confident electronic bed with soft pads and light plucks, controlled energy.

asset.description: The camera starts with a close-up on a vintage instant camera sitting on a cluttered office desk, surrounded by miniature figurines labeled with masking tape tags like “user,” “order,” and “config.” A disembodied hand gently nudges all the figurines into a tight cluster in the center of the desk, then presses the camera shutter with exaggerated slowness. The lens cover falls off clumsily, dangling on a string, as a blank white photo wheezes out and flops onto the desk. The shot cuts to a top-down view as the person frantically fans the photo with both hands in an over-the-top attempt to make it develop faster, occasionally blowing on it and checking it like it’s a Polaroid status screen. As the image finally darkens, it reveals all the figurines frozen in their exact positions, with the word “DEFFACTS” scribbled in bold marker across the bottom margin. The person then carefully slides the photo into a plastic sleeve labeled “WORLD SNAPSHOT” and flips a big comically oversized toggle switch next to it from “OFF” to “ASSERT,” causing a messy bin full of loose figurines to rattle slightly as if an invisible force just organized them.

bgm: Chill groove with retro synths, slightly nostalgic but upbeat.

asset.description: Scene opens on a long dining table arranged like an absurd board game, with three labeled zones taped onto the surface: “FACTS” on the left, “RULES” in the middle, and “AGENDA” on the right. A person wearing a referee shirt and a wizard hat stands at the head of the table holding a tiny gavel. From a low, dramatic angle, the camera watches as they slide colored index cards with scribbles from the FACTS zone toward the RULES zone, carefully lining them up as if they’re puzzle pieces. As certain cards touch, the person’s eyes go wide and they slam the gavel on the table; in sync, they flick a matching card into the AGENDA zone with an exaggerated wrist snap, sending it spinning and skidding to a perfect stop. The camera jump-cuts to a close-up of the AGENDA zone where cards are stacked haphazardly like a chaotic to-do list, then tilts up to show the person pointing at the top card and mouthing the word “fire” while miming a tiny explosion with their fingers. They then ceremoniously pick up that top card, hold it up to their forehead like it’s a VIP ticket, and drop it onto a small metal tray marked “FIRED,” where other cards lie crumpled, slightly singed around the edges with marker scribbles like “done.”

bgm: Driving electro-orchestral hybrid, ticking rhythmic pulse to imply machinery and logic.

asset.description: The shot opens with a close-up of a person wearing an oversized trench coat and a comically large magnifying glass, hunched over a laptop whose screen is filled with rapidly scrolling monochrome text. The room is dramatically underlit by a single desk lamp that flickers slightly, giving the scene an over-the-top noir vibe. The camera slowly tracks in from the side as the person slams the keyboard with two fingers, causing the screen to freeze mid-scroll and highlight a single line in bright green. They squint through the magnifying glass at the highlighted line, then look up at a cluttered corkboard behind the laptop, pinned with index cards labeled “FACTS,” “RULES,” and “AGENDA,” all connected by red yarn like a conspiracy diagram. In an exaggerated move, they grab a pushpin labeled “refraction,” jab it dramatically between two yarn lines, and then step back to admire how the overlapping strings now form a crooked but satisfying triangle. The camera shifts to a low angle as they spin the magnifying glass toward the viewer, briefly distorting their face into a giant floating eyeball that blinks slowly before snapping back to normal.

bgm: Low-key suspenseful groove with muted bass and soft hi-hats, detective-mystery vibe but lighthearted.

asset.description: Camera begins with a tight frontal shot of a person sitting cross-legged on the floor in front of a plain wall, wearing three different pairs of glasses stacked on their nose and forehead—reading glasses, neon party glasses, and welding goggles—while holding a whiteboard marker like a magic wand. As the camera slowly pulls back, the wall behind them is revealed to be covered in rows of sticky notes shaped like stars, each with cryptic scribbles such as “?x,” “$rest,” and “*_wild.” The person reaches up dramatically and plucks a star-shaped note labeled “variable” from high above their head, sticks it on their own forehead, and then freezes with a comically intense stare at the camera. The shot jump-cuts wider as they begin rapidly rearranging the star sticky notes into constellations, tracing lines between them with big looping gestures as if mapping the night sky; each completed cluster vaguely forms shapes like a dog or a galaxy swirl. The person then lies flat on the floor under the wall of notes, stretching both arms upward toward a cluster labeled “multifield,” as if basking in its cosmic power, while one of the stacked glasses slowly slides down their face and dangles off one ear in perfect deadpan.

bgm: Expansive but bouncy electronic track with subtle “cosmic” synths, sense of discovery.

asset.description: Shot opens on a miniature cardboard city laid out on a table, with tiny buildings made from cereal boxes labeled as facts, each one tagged with a hand-written “id” on a sticky note. A person wearing bright yellow construction gloves and a reflective safety vest looms over the city like an overenthusiastic city planner. From a low city-street perspective, the camera watches as a toy crane with a dangling hook slowly lowers onto one of the buildings; with a jerky overacted motion, the person uses the crane to gently drop a new building onto an empty lot, then slaps a big “ASSERTED” label onto it. The shot jump-cuts to another angle where they dramatically pluck a different building straight upward with their bare hand, leaving behind the lonely sticky-note id fluttering on the table, and then toss the building into a nearby shoebox labeled “RETRACTED” with a muffled clunk. Finally, they kneel down and very carefully peel the label off an existing building, scribble over it while keeping the same id visible, and re-stick it as “MODIFIED,” then turn to the camera and give an absurdly serious nod while tiny cardboard pedestrians painted on the streets lean slightly from the earlier disturbance.

bgm: Playful but methodical marimba-and-synth groove, medium tempo, mechanical feel.

asset.description: The camera begins with a close-up of a messy pegboard wall in a garage, where normal tools like hammers and wrenches hang side by side with absurdly labeled laminated cards reading “list,” “delete,” “save-facts,” “load-facts,” “run 1,” and “watch.” A person in a mechanic jumpsuit and thick safety goggles stands in front of the wall holding a bright pink toolbox that is clearly too small for its contents, bulging slightly at the seams. In a fast-paced sequence of choreographed moves, they snap open the toolbox, pull out a random tool card with a flourish, and slap it onto an empty peg, where it swings back and forth like a wind chime. The camera quickly cuts between angles as they grab different tools—a plastic toy hammer for “run 1,” a giant novelty eraser for “delete,” a floppy disk keychain for “save/load facts”—and mime using them on a nearby whiteboard cluttered with fake rule names, making overacted impact gestures each time. The final shot zooms in on their grease-smeared hand dramatically twisting an imaginary dial labeled “COMPLEXITY” from chaos to a tidy checked box, while all the tool cards on the pegboard sway gently as if the whole system just settled into place.

bgm: Upbeat, slightly funky electronic track with quick transitions that support montage cuts.

asset.description: Scene opens with a wide shot of a gigantic sheet of butcher paper taped to a wall, so large it nearly covers the entire background. A person armed with four different colored markers stands in front of it like a sports commentator, wearing a headset microphone and wildly mismatched socks visible under business slacks that are slightly too short. In one long, chaotic take, they speed-draw a diagram: first, they scribble a box labeled “facts = data,” then immediately draw an arrow to “deftemplates / deffacts,” underlining it so hard the paper wrinkles. Without breaking motion, they pivot to sketch another box labeled “rules = behavior,” punctuating it with a dramatic dot that accidentally leaves a small ink splatter on their sleeve. The camera slowly creeps closer as they connect everything to a big bubble in the center reading “inference engine + agenda = control,” circling it so many times the marker squeaks audibly. They cap it off by writing “variables & wildcards” at the top of the sheet in oversized, wobbly letters, then spin around and double finger-gun the camera as if they just revealed a championship play.

bgm: Confident recap music with steady beat, slightly inspirational but still nerdy and light.

asset.description: The shot starts with a close-up of a small notebook on a desk, its first page titled “Tiny Expert System” in bubble letters, surrounded by color-coded sticky notes reading “templates,” “deffacts,” “rules,” and “watch.” A hand rapidly flips through the pages, each one crammed with chaotic doodles of boxes, arrows, and lightning bolts, until the camera pulls back to reveal a person perched on a rolling office chair, spinning slowly in place like a loading icon while holding a marker between their teeth. They abruptly stop spinning, yank the marker from their mouth like a sword, and point it dramatically at the camera, then at a nearby laptop where an editor window with fake CLIPS code is open. The scene cuts to an overhead shot of them furiously arranging the sticky notes into a neat linear pipeline across the desk, numbering them “1” through “5” with theatrical arm sweeps. In the final frame, they slide a giant cardboard arrow labeled “FOLLOW” into the shot and place it beside a cartoonishly large subscribe button drawn on paper, then give the camera an exaggerated, pleading wide-eyed stare while offering a thumbs-up with both hands.

bgm: Upbeat, motivational electronic track with a satisfying resolve at the end, slightly triumphant.
